class_d_01_language_01:
Meus alunos! Como estão todos hoje?
Tudo bem?[npcn:2C]
class_d_01_language_02: Je m'appelle Salvatore. Meu nome é Salvatore![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_03:
Merci beaucoup! Ou seja, muito obrigado por
sua atenção aqui na minha aula![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_04:
Estou tão heureux — ou feliz — pela chance
reviver meus dias de juventude com vocês![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_05:
Sabem o que significa “Salvatore”? Significa
“salvador”! Acreditem que estou aqui para
SALVA-LOS de idiomas assustadores. Haha![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_06:
Isso mesmo! Minhas aulas ensinarão vários
idiomas de diferentes regiões.[npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_07:
Você pode dizer "Bom dia!" ou “Olá!”, mas
pessoas de outros lugares podem dizer\r
“Bonjour!” ou “Salut!”[npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_08:
Ouvi dizer que existe até um streamer popular
por aí que combina vários idiomas\r
e diz “'Ello, ’ello, hola!! Ciao e bonjour!”[npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_09:
Existem muitas regiões em nosso mundo,
e cada uma tem seu próprio idioma![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_10:
Gracias, merci, xièxie, arigato, danke - tudo isso
tem o mesmo significado! Você pode dizer qual?[npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_answer_01:
Oh! [trnm:0], was it?\c
That’s not quite right, but your willingness to
speak up will serve you well in language learning![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_answer_02:
Waouh! [trnm:0], was it?\c
Brav[o;a:g]! That’s correct! And speaking up is
important in language learning, too![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_answer_03:
Oh! [trnm:0], was it?\c
That’s not quite right, but your willingness to
speak up will serve you well in language learning![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_11:
Gracias, merci, xièxie—these words all mean
“thank you.” I guess some of you probably knew\r
at least one of those![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_12:
Despite meaning the same thing, their lengths
and sounds are all different! Isn’t that interesting?[npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_13:
And now, apropos of nothing, let me give you
all one of my wise words of advice![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_14:
When you travel abroad, you should try to speak
the local language as much as you can—even if\r
you can’t speak it very well![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_15:
I’m sure your willingness to try will make the
people you meet très heureux—very happy![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_16:
Honestly, from my experience, just being able to
say “hello,” “delicious,” and “thank you” in the\r
local language will get you pretty far.[npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_17:
For everything else, just pretend you’re Mr. Mime
and gesture away![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_18:
Oh! There’s that pesky bell. I guess that’s all the
time we have for today![npcn:26]
class_d_01_language_19:
Well, adios! Mata ne! À la prochaine! See you
later, everyone![npcn:26]
